info.title: IBM Cloud Secrets Manager API
info.description:
With IBM Cloud® Secrets Manager, you can create, lease, and centrally manage secrets that are used in IBM Cloud
services or your custom-built applications. Secrets are stored in a dedicated instance of Secrets Manager, built on
open source HashiCorp Vault.
info.x-cli-description: Use the IBM Cloud® Secrets Manager service to create and manage secrets that are used in other IBM Cloud services or your custom-built applications.

source: With IBM Cloud® Secrets Manager, you can create, lease, and centrally manage secrets that are used in IBM Cloud services or your custom-built applications. Secrets are stored in a dedicated instance of Secrets Manager, built on open source HashiCorp Vault.

SDKs for Java, Node, Python, and Go are available to make it easier to programmatically access the API from your code. The client libraries that are provided by the SDKs implement best practices for using the API and reduce the amount of code that you need to write. The tab for each language includes code examples that demonstrate how to use the client libraries.
For more information about using the SDKs, see the IBM Cloud SDK Common project on GitHub. For more information about getting started with Secrets Manager, check out the docs.
Replace {version} in these examples with the release version.
Go modules (recommended): Add the following import in your code, and then run go build or go mod tidy

Secrets Manager supports instance-specific endpoint URLs that you can use to interact with the service over public or private service endpoints. To make requests to the API, you supply the instance ID that is unique to your Secrets Manager service instance.
You can copy your endpoint URL from the Endpoints page in the Secrets Manager service dashboard.

Secrets Manager supports instance-specific endpoint URLs that you can use to interact with the service over public or private service endpoints. To target your Secrets Manager service instance by using the Java SDK, use the setServiceUrl() method. You can copy your endpoint URL from the Endpoints page in the Secrets Manager service dashboard.
If you copy the endpoint URL from your Secrets Manager service dashboard, be sure to trim /api from the URL to use it with the SDK.

Secrets Manager supports instance-specific endpoint URLs that you can use to interact with the service over public or private service endpoints. To target your Secrets Manager service instance by using the Node.js SDK, use the serviceUrl parameter. You can copy your endpoint URL from the Endpoints page in the Secrets Manager service dashboard.
If you copy the endpoint URL from your Secrets Manager service dashboard, be sure to trim /api from the URL to use it with the SDK.

Secrets Manager supports instance-specific endpoint URLs that you can use to interact with the service over public or private service endpoints. To target your Secrets Manager service instance by using the Python SDK, use the set_service_url() method. You can copy your endpoint URL from the Endpoints page in the Secrets Manager service dashboard.
If you copy the endpoint URL from your Secrets Manager service dashboard, be sure to trim /api from the URL to use it with the SDK.

Secrets Manager supports instance-specific endpoint URLs that you can use to interact with the service over public or private service endpoints. To target your Secrets Manager service instance by using the Go SDK, use the URL parameter. You can copy your endpoint URL from the Endpoints page in the Secrets Manager service dashboard.
If you copy the endpoint URL from your Secrets Manager service dashboard, be sure to trim /api from the URL to use it with the SDK.

Authorization to the Secrets Manager API is enforced by using an IBM Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) access token. The token is used to determine the actions that a user or service ID has access to when they use the API.

To work with the API, include a valid IAM token in each outgoing request to the service. You can generate an access token by first creating an API key and then exchanging your API key for an IBM Cloud IAM token.
Don't have an API key? Try running ibmcloud iam oauth-tokens in the IBM Cloud Shell to quickly generate a personal access token.
To generate an access token from your API key, use the following cURL command.

curl -X POST \
  "https://iam.cloud.ibm.com/identity/token" \
  --header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --header 'Accept: application/json' \
  --data-urlencode 'grant_type=urn:ibm:params:oauth:grant-type:apikey' \
  --data-urlencode 'apikey=<API_KEY>'
Replace <API_KEY> with your IBM Cloud API key.

When you use the SDK, configure an IAM authenticator with an IBM Cloud IAM API key. The authenticator automatically obtains the IAM access token for the API key and includes it with each request. You can configure an authenticator in either of two ways:

• Programmatically by constructing an IAM authenticator instance and supplying your IAM API key
  • By defining the API key in external configuration properties and then using the SDK authenticator factory to construct an IAM authenticator that uses the configured IAM API key
For more information, see the Authentication section of the IBM Cloud SDK Common documentation.
Replace <API_KEY> with your IBM Cloud API key. Replace <URL> with the endpoint URL for your instance. Invoke service operations by using the sm variable.
Replace <API_KEY> with your IBM Cloud API key. Replace <URL> with the endpoint URL for your instance.
Replace <API_KEY> with your IBM Cloud API key. Replace <URL> with the endpoint URL for your instance.
Replace <API_KEY> with your IBM Cloud API key. Replace <URL> with the endpoint URL for your instance.

<!--
# Basic usage

## Java middle-pane content only

With the Java SDK, you can build a service client for the Secrets Manager by implementing the `SecretsManager` class within the `com.ibm.cloud.platform_services.configuration-governance.v1` package. To construct the client, you can set your options programmatically, or you can define external configuration properties to be used by your application.

The examples that are provided on this page demonstrate how to build a service client by using these two options. For more information and detailed examples, check out the [IBM Cloud SDK Common project on GitHub](https://github.com/IBM/ibm-cloud-sdk-common/blob/master/README.md){: external}.

## Go middle-pane content only

With the Go SDK, you can build a service client for the Secrets Manager by implementing the `IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1` class within the `IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1` package. To construct the client, you can set your options programmatically, or you can define external configuration properties to be used by your application.

The examples that are provided on this page demonstrate how to build a service client by using these two options. For more information and detailed examples, check out the [IBM Cloud SDK Common project on GitHub](https://github.com/IBM/ibm-cloud-sdk-common/blob/master/README.md){: external}.

## Python middle-pane content only

With the Python SDK, you can build a service client for the Secrets Manager by implementing the `IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1` class within the `ibm-platform-services` module. To construct the client, you can set your options programmatically, or you can define external configuration properties to be used by your application.

The examples that are provided on this page demonstrate how to build a service client by using these two options. For more information and detailed examples, check out the [IBM Cloud SDK Common project on GitHub](https://github.com/IBM/ibm-cloud-sdk-common/blob/master/README.md){: external}.



## Node middle-pane content only

With the Node.js SDK, you can build a service client for the Secrets Manager service by implementing the `IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1` class within the `ibm-cloud-secrets-manager-api/v1` module.

The examples that are provided on this page demonstrate how to build a service client by using programmatic credentials. For more information and detailed examples, check out the [IBM Cloud SDK Common project on GitHub](https://github.com/IBM/ibm-cloud-sdk-common/blob/master/README.md){: external}.

## Node.js right-pane example


Example
```javascript
const IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1 =  require('@ibm-cloud/secrets-manager/ibm-cloud-secrets-manager-api/v1');
const { IamAuthenticator } = require('@ibm-cloud/secrets-manager/auth');


async function secretsManagerSdkExample() {

  // Authenticate with IAM by using your IBM Cloud API key
  const authenticator = new IamAuthenticator({
    apikey: process.env.SECRETS_MANAGER_API_APIKEY,
  });

  // Create an instance of the SDK
  const secretsManagerApi = new IbmCloudSecretsManagerApiV1({
    authenticator,
    serviceUrl:
      'https://example-instance.us-south.secrets-manager.appdomain.cloud',
  });

  // Use the Secrets Manager API to create a secret
  let res = await secretsManagerApi.createSecret({
    secretType: 'username_password',
    'metadata': {
      'collection_type': 'application/vnd.ibm.secrets-manager.secret+json',
      'collection_total': 1,
    },
    'resources': [
      {
        'name': 'example-username-password-secret',
        'description': 'Extended description for this secret.',
        'username': 'user123',
        'password': 'cloudy-rainy-coffee-book',
        'labels': ['dev', 'us-south'],
        'expiration_date': '2030-04-01T09:30:00Z',
      },
    ],
  });

  console.log('Secret created:\n' + JSON.stringify(res.result.resources[0], null, 2));

  // Get the ID of the newly created secret
  const secretId = res.result.resources[0].id;

  // Get the secret by using the secret ID
  res = await secretsManagerApi.getSecret({
    secretType: 'username_password',
    id: secretId,
  });

  console.log('Get Secret:\n', JSON.stringify(res.result.resources, null, 2));
}

secretsManagerSdkExample();
```
-->

You can monitor API activity within your account by using the IBM Cloud Activity Tracker service. Whenever an API method is called, an event is generated that you can then track and audit from within Activity Tracker. The specific event type is listed for each individual method.
For more information about how to track Secrets Manager activity, see Auditing events for Secrets Manager.

The Secrets Manager APIs use standard HTTP status codes to indicate whether a method completed successfully. HTTP response codes in the 2xx range indicate success. A response in the 4xx range is some sort of failure, and a response in the 5xx range usually indicates an internal system error.

Status code summary
Status code Description
200 OK Everything worked as expected.
201 OK Everything worked as expected. No content is returned.
400 Bad Request The request was unsuccessful, often due to a missing required parameter.
401 Unauthorized The parameters were valid but the request failed due insufficient permissions.
404 Not Found The requested resource doesn't exist.
409 Conflict The requested resource conflicts with an already existing resource.
410 Gone The requested resource was deleted and no longer exists.
429 Too Many Requests Too many requests hit the API too quickly.
500 Internal Server Error Something went wrong on Secrets Manager's end.

<!--
# Additional headers

### Request headers

The Secrets Manager API accepts custom parameters that you can pass in as part of your request. For example, you can generate a correlation ID and supply it in a custom `correlation-id` request header.

To pass a request header, use the `--header` (`-H`) option with a cURL request.

## Curl right-pane example

Example request header

```bash
curl -X {request_method} "{url}/{method}" --header 'Correlation-Id: {header_value}'
```

### Response headers

When a method completes successfully, this API might return custom information to your application in response headers. For example, each response includes a `correlation-id` header that can be referenced when you contact [IBM Cloud support](https://www.ibm.com/cloud/support){: external}.

To access all response headers, you can include the `--include` (`-i`) option in your cURL request. To see detailed response data for the request, such as request headers, response headers, and extra debugging information, include the `--verbose` (`-v`) option.

## Curl right-pane example

Example request to access response headers

```bash
curl --include -X {request_method} "{url}/{method}"
```
-->
Some API requests might return a large number of results. To avoid performance issues, the Secrets Manager API returns one page of results at a time, with a limited number of results on each page.
The default page size is 200 objects. To use a different page size, use the limit query parameter.
Secrets Manager limits API requests to 20 requests per second on a per-service-instance basis.

If the number of requests reaches the request limit (20 requests) within the specified time window (1 second), no further requests are accepted until a timer expires. After the timer expires, a new time window begins with the next accepted request.

An HTTP status code of 429 indicates that the rate limit has been exceeded. If you exceed the rate limit, the API also sends the following response header that you can use to determine how long to wait before sending another request.
• Retry-After: The number of seconds to delay after the response is received before making a follow-up request.
To access the Retry-After response header, you can supply the the --include (-i) option in your cURL request. For example, curl --include -X {request_method} "{base_url}/api/v1/{method_endpoint}".
For the latest changes, improvements, and updates for this API, see the API change log.

externalDocs.description: For more information about this service, see the docs.

tags.name: Secret groups
tags.description: Control who on your team has access to secrets by creating and managing groups.

tags.name: Secrets
tags.description: Create, import, and manage different types of secrets for your apps and services.

tags.name: Config
tags.description: Configure secrets engines for your instance so that you can work with specific types of secrets.

post.description:
Creates a secret group that you can use to organize secrets and control who on your team has access to them.

A successful request returns the ID value of the secret group, along with other metadata. To learn more about
secret groups, check out the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-secret-groups).
post.x-cli-description: Create a secret group to organize secrets and control who on your team has access to them.
post.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The secret group was successfully created.

python.signature:
create_secret_group(self,
        metadata: 'CollectionMetadata',
        resources: List['SecretGroupResource'],
        **kwargs
    ) -> DetailedResponse

go.alternateSignature: (secretsManager *SecretsManagerV1) CreateSecretGroupWithContext(ctx context.Context, createSecretGroupOptions *CreateSecretGroupOptions) (result *SecretGroupDef, response *core.DetailedResponse, err error)

get.description: Retrieves the list of secret groups that are available in your Secrets Manager instance.
get.x-cli-description: List the secret groups that are available in your Secrets Manager instance.
get.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The list of secret groups was successfully retrieved.

source:
listSecretGroupsOptions := secretsManagerApi.NewListSecretGroupsOptions()

result, response, err := secretsManagerApi.ListSecretGroups(listSecretGroupsOptions)
if err != nil {
    panic(err)
}

b, _ := json.MarshalIndent(result, "", "  ")
fmt.Println(string(b))

go.alternateSignature: (secretsManager *SecretsManagerV1) ListSecretGroupsWithContext(ctx context.Context, listSecretGroupsOptions *ListSecretGroupsOptions) (result *SecretGroupDef, response *core.DetailedResponse, err error)

delete.description:
Deletes a secret group by specifying the ID of the secret group.

**Note:** To delete a secret group, it must be empty. If you need to remove a secret group that contains secrets,
you must first [delete the secrets](#delete-secret) that are associated with the group.
delete.x-cli-description: Delete a secret group. To delete a group that has contained secrets, be sure to first delete the secrets that are associated with the group.
delete.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

204.description: The secret group was successfully deleted.

python.signature:
delete_secret_group(self,
        id: str,
        **kwargs
    ) -> DetailedResponse

go.alternateSignature: (secretsManager *SecretsManagerV1) DeleteSecretGroupWithContext(ctx context.Context, deleteSecretGroupOptions *DeleteSecretGroupOptions) (response *core.DetailedResponse, err error)

post.description:
Creates a secret or imports an existing value that you can use to access or authenticate to a protected resource.

Use this method to either generate or import an existing secret, such as an arbitrary value or a TLS certificate,
that you can manage in your Secrets Manager service instance. A successful request stores the secret in your
dedicated instance based on the secret type and data that you specify. The response returns the ID value of the
secret, along with other metadata.

To learn more about the types of secrets that you can create with Secrets Manager, check out the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-what-is-secret).
post.x-cli-description: Create a secret and store it in your instance.
post.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

CreateArbitrarySecret.description: Example response for creating an `arbitrary` secret.

CreateUsernamePasswordSecret.description: Example response for creating a `username_password` secret.

CreateIAMCredentialsSecret.description: Example response for creating an `iam_credentials` secret.

ImportCertificate.description: Example response for importing a TLS certificate

OrderCertificate.description: Example response for Ordering a TLS certificate

python.signature:
create_secret(self,
        secret_type: str,
        metadata: 'CollectionMetadata',
        resources: List['SecretResource'],
        **kwargs
    ) -> DetailedResponse

go.alternateSignature: (secretsManager *SecretsManagerV1) CreateSecretWithContext(ctx context.Context, createSecretOptions *CreateSecretOptions) (result *CreateSecret, response *core.DetailedResponse, err error)

get.description: Retrieves a list of secrets based on the type that you specify.
get.x-cli-description: List secrets in your instance based on the type that you specify.
get.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The list of secrets was successfully retrieved.

source:
response = secretsManager.get_secret(
    secret_type='arbitrary',
    id=secret_id_link
).get_result()

print(json.dumps(response, indent=2))

get.description:
Retrieves a secret and its details by specifying the ID of the secret.

A successful request returns the secret data that is associated with your secret, along with other metadata. To
view only the details of a specified secret without retrieving its value, use the [Get secret metadata](#get-secret-metadata)
method.
get.x-cli-description: Get a secret and its details. This command returns the secret data that is associated with your secret.
get.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

response = secretsManager.get_secret(
    secret_type='arbitrary',
    id=secret_id_link
).get_result()

print(json.dumps(response, indent=2))

post.summary: Invoke an action on a secret

descriptionMap.delete_credentials: Delete the Cloud IAM API key that is associated with a secret

post.description:
Invokes an action on a specified secret. This method supports the following actions:

- `rotate`: Replace the value of an `arbitrary`, `username_password`, `public_cert` or `imported_cert` secret. 
- `delete_credentials`: Delete the API key that is associated with an `iam_credentials` secret.
post.x-cli-description: Invoke an action on a secret.
post.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

parameters.name: action
parameters.description: The action to perform on the specified secret.
parameters.x-cli-description: The action to perform on the secret. Supported options include `rotate` and `delete_credentials`.

200.description: The action on the secret completed successfully.

rotate.description: Example response for rotating a `username_password` secret.

202.description: Your request to rotate the certicate was accepted.

rotate.description: Example response for rotating a `public_cert` secret.

204.description: The `delete_credentials` action on the secret completed successfully.

python.signature:
update_secret(self,
        secret_type: str,
        id: str,
        action: str,
        secret_action: 'SecretAction',
        **kwargs
    ) -> DetailedResponse

go.alternateSignature: (secretsManager *SecretsManagerV1) UpdateSecretWithContext(ctx context.Context, updateSecretOptions *UpdateSecretOptions) (result *GetSecret, response *core.DetailedResponse, err error)

get.description:
Retrieves the details of a secret by specifying the ID.

A successful request returns only metadata about the secret, such as its name and creation date. To retrieve the
value of a secret, use the [Get a secret](#get-secret) or [Get a version of a secret](#get-secret-version) methods.
get.x-cli-description: Get the metadata of a secret, such as its name and creation date. To retrieve the value of a secret, use `ibmcloud secrets-manager secret --secret-type SECRET-TYPE --id ID`.
get.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The secret's metadata was successfully retrieved.

Updates the metadata of a secret, such as its name or description.

To update the actual contents of a secret, rotate the secret by using the [Invoke an action on a secret](#update-secret)
method.
put.x-cli-description: Update the metadata of a secret, such as its name or description. To rotate the value of a secret, use `ibmcloud secrets-manager secret-update --secret-type SECRET-TYPE --id ID --action rotate`.
put.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The secret's metadata was successfully updated.

put.description:
Creates or updates one or more policies, such as an [automatic rotation policy](http://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-rotate-secrets#auto-rotate-secret),
for the specified secret.
put.x-cli-description: Set a rotation policy for a secret.
put.x-rate-limit: This operation is limited to 20 requests per 1 second per service instance.

200.description: The policy or policies were successfully created or updated.

        secret_type: str,
        id: str,
        metadata: 'CollectionMetadata',
        resources: List['SecretPolicyRotation'],

        **kwargs

put.summary: Set the configuration of a secret type
put.description:
Sets the configuration for the specified secret type.

Use this method to configure the IAM credentials (`iam_credentials`) engine for your service
instance. Looking to set up certificate ordering? To configure the public certificates (`public_cert`)
engine, use the [Add a configuration](#create_config_element) method.

Use this method to define the configurations that are required to enable the  public certificates (`public_cert`)
engine. You can add up to 10 certificate authority and DNS provider configurations for your instance.

PoliciesSecretType.name: secret_type
PoliciesSecretType.x-cli-description: The secret type. Supported options include: public_cert, username_password

ConfigSecretType.name: secret_type
ConfigSecretType.x-cli-description: The secret type. Supported options include: public_cert, iam_credentials

VersionSupportedSecretType.description: The secret type. Supported options include: imported_cert
VersionSupportedSecretType.name: secret_type

SecretType.name: secret_type
SecretType.x-cli-description: The secret type. Supported options include: arbitrary, iam_credentials, imported_cert, public_cert, username_password

ConfigElementType.name: config_element
ConfigElementType.description: The configuration element to define or manage.
ConfigElementType.x-cli-description: The configuration element to define or manage.

LimitParam.name: limit
LimitParam.description:
The number of secrets to retrieve. By default, list operations return the first 200 items. To retrieve a different set
of items, use `limit` with `offset` to page through your available resources.

**Usage:** If you have 20 secrets in your instance, and you want to retrieve only the first 5 secrets, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?limit=5`.
LimitParam.x-cli-description: The number of secrets to list.

OffsetParam.name: offset
OffsetParam.description:
The number of secrets to skip. By specifying `offset`, you retrieve a subset of items that starts with the `offset`
value. Use `offset` with `limit` to page through your available resources.

**Usage:** If you have 100 secrets in your instance, and you want to retrieve secrets 26 through 50, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?offset=25&limit=25`.
OffsetParam.x-cli-description: The number of secrets to skip.

SearchParam.name: search
SearchParam.description:
Filter secrets that contain the specified string. The fields that are searched include: id, name, description,
labels, secret_type.

**Usage:** If you want to list only the secrets that contain the string "text", use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?search=text`.
SearchParam.x-cli-description: Filter secrets that contain the specified string.

SortByParam.name: sort_by
SortByParam.description:
Sort a list of secrets by the specified field.

**Usage:** To sort a list of secrets by their creation date, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?sort_by=creation_date`.
SortByParam.x-cli-description: Sort a list of secrets by the specified field.

GroupsParam.name: groups
GroupsParam.description:
Filter secrets by groups.

You can apply multiple filters by using a comma-separated list of secret group IDs. If you need to filter secrets
that are in the default secret group, use the `default` keyword.

**Usage:** To retrieve a list of secrets that are associated with an existing secret group or the default group,
use `../secrets?groups={secret_group_ID},default`.

SecretId.name: id
SecretId.description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret.

VersionId.name: version_id
VersionId.description:
The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret version. You can also use `previous` to retrieve the previous
version.

**Note:** To find the version ID of a secret, use the [Get secret metadata](#get-secret-metadata) method and
check the response details.
VersionId.x-cli-description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret version. Use `previous` to retrieve the previous version.

SecretGroupId.name: id
SecretGroupId.description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret group.

SecretPolicyType.description: The type of policy that is associated with the specified secret.
SecretPolicyType.x-cli-description: The type of policy. Currently, `rotation` is supported.
SecretPolicyType.name: policy

SecretId.description: Link to the secret ID parameter.

SecretGroupId.description: Link to the secret group ID parameter.

State.description: The secret state based on NIST SP 800-57. States are integers and correspond to the Pre-activation = 0, Active = 1,  Suspended = 2, Deactivated = 3, and Destroyed = 5 values.

StateDescription.description: A text representation of the secret state.

Issuer.description: The distinguished name that identifies the entity that signed and issued the certificate.

SerialNumber.description: The unique serial number that was assigned to the certificate by the issuing certificate authority.

auto_rotate.description:
Determines whether Secrets Manager rotates your certificate automatically.

If set to `true`, the service reorders your certificate 31 days before it expires. To access the previous 
version of the certifcate, you can use the [Get a version of a secret](#get-secret-version) method.

rotate_keys.description:
Determines whether Secrets Manager rotates the private key for your certificate automatically.

If set to `true`, the service generates and stores a new private key for your rotated certificate.

IssuanceInfo.description: Issuance information that is associated with your certificate.

ordered_on.description: The date the certificate was ordered. The date format follows RFC 3339.

error_code.description:
An code that identifies an issuance error.

This field, along with `error_message`, is returned when Secrets Manager successfully processes your request,
but a certificate is unable to be issued by the certificate authority.

error_message.description: A human-readable message that provides details about the issuance error.

bundle_certs.description: Indicates whether the issued certificate is bundled with intermediate certificates.

auto_rotated.description: Indicates whether the issued certificate is configured with an automatic rotation policy.

ca.description: The name that was assigned to the certificate authority configuration.

dns.description: The name that was assigned to the DNS provider configuration.

CertificateAuthorityConfigPrivateKey.description: The private key that is associated with your certificate authority account.

CaType.description:
The certificate authority to sign and issue your certificates.

Currently, Let's Encrypt is supported. Choose between two options:

- `letsencrypt-stage`: Staging environment for Let's Encrypt.
- `letsencrypt`: Production environment for Let's Encrypt.
CaType.x-cli-description: The certificate authority to sign and issue certificates. Supported options: letsencrypt-stage, letsencrypt

ConfigElementName.description: The human-readable name to assign to your configuration.

ConfigElementType.description: The type of configuration. Value options differ depending on the `config_element` property that you want to define.

BaseSecretVersionMetadata.description: Properties that describe a secret version.

auto_rotated.description: Indicates whether the version of the secret was created by automatic rotation.

CollectionMetadata.description: The metadata that describes the resource array.

collection_type.description: The type of resources in the resource array.

collection_total.description: The number of elements in the resource array.

SecretGroupResource.description: Properties that describe a secret group.

id.description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret group.

name.description:
A human-readable name to assign to your secret group.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a name for your secret group.
name.x-cli-description: The type of policy. Currently, `rotation` is supported.

description.description:
An extended description of your secret group.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a description for your
secret group.

creation_date.description: The date the secret group was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.

last_update_date.description: Updates when the metadata of the secret group is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.

type.description: The MIME type that represents the secret group.

id.description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret.

name.description:
A human-readable alias to assign to your secret.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as an alias for your secret.

description.description:
An extended description of your secret.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a description for your
secret.

secret_group_id.description:
The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret group to assign to this secret.

If you omit this parameter, your secret is assigned to the `default` secret group.

labels.description:
Labels that you can use to filter for secrets in your instance.

Up to 30 labels can be created. Labels can be between 2-30 characters, including spaces. Special characters not
permitted include the angled bracket, comma, colon, ampersand, and vertical pipe character (|).

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a label for your secret.

crn.description: The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies your Secrets Manager resource.

creation_date.description: The date the secret was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.

created_by.description: The unique identifier for the entity that created the secret.

last_update_date.description: Updates when the actual secret is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.

versions_total.description: The number of versions that are associated with a secret.

versions.description: An array that contains metadata for each secret version. For more information on the metadata properties, see [Get secret version metadata](#get-secret-version-metadata).

payload.description: The new secret data to assign to the secret.

next_rotation_date.description:
The date that the secret is scheduled for automatic rotation.

The service automatically creates a new version of the secret on its next rotation date. This field exists
only for secrets that can be auto-rotated and have an existing rotation policy.

access_groups.description:
The access groups that define the capabilities of the service ID and API key that are generated for an
`iam_credentials` secret.

**Tip:** To find the ID of an access group, go to **Manage > Access (IAM) > Access groups** in the IBM Cloud
console. Select the access group to inspect, and click **Details** to view its ID.

api_key.description:
The API key that is generated for this secret.

After the secret reaches the end of its lease (see the `ttl` field), the API key is deleted automatically.
If you want to continue to use the same API key for future read operations, see the `reuse_api_key` field.

service_id.description:
The service ID under which the API key (see the `api_key` field) is created. This service ID is added
to the access groups that you assign for this secret.

reuse_api_key.description:
Set to `true` to reuse the service ID and API key for this secret.

Use this field to control whether to use the same service ID and API key for future read operations on
this secret. If set to `true`, the service reuses the current credentials. If set to `false`, a new service
ID and API key is generated each time that the secret is read or accessed.
reuse_api_key.x-cli-description: (IAM credentials) Reuse the service ID and API key for future read operations.

certificate.description:
The contents of your certificate. The data must be formatted on a single line with embedded newline
characters.

private_key.description:
The private key to associate with the certificate. The data must be formatted on a single line with
embedded newline characters.
private_key.x-cli-description: (Optional) The private key to associate with the certificate.

intermediate.description:
The intermediate certificate to associate with the root certificate. The data must be formatted on a
single line with embedded newline characters.
intermediate.x-cli-description: (Optional) The intermediate certificate to associate with the root certificate.

algorithm.description:
The identifier for the cryptographic algorthim that was used by the issuing certificate authority to
sign the ceritificate.

key_algorithm.description:
The identifier for the cryptographic algorithm that was used to generate the public key that is
associated with the certificate.

issuer.description: The distinguished name that identifies the entity that signed and issued the certificate.

common_name.description: The fully qualified domain name or host domain name that is defined for the certificate.

intermediate_included.description: Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated intermediate certificate.

private_key_included.description: Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated private key.

alt_names.description: The alternative names that are defined for the certificate.

bundle_certs.description:
Determines whether your issued certificate is bundled with intermediate certificates.

Set to `false` for the certificate file to contain only the issued certificate.

ca.description:
The name of the certificate authority configuration.

To view a list of your configured authorities, use the [List configurations](#get-secret-config-element)
method.

creation_date.description: The date the secret was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.

created_by.description: The unique identifier for the entity that created the secret.

last_update_date.description: Updates when any part of the secret metadata is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.

versions_total.description: The number of versions the secret has.

ArbitrarySecretMetadata.description: Metadata properties that describe an arbitrary secret.

UsernamePasswordSecretMetadata.description: Metadata properties that describe a username_password secret.

IAMCredentialsSecretMetadata.description: Metadata properties that describe a iam_credentials secret.

reuse_api_key.description:
For `iam_credentials` secrets, this field controls whether to use the same service ID and API key for future read operations on
this secret. If set to `true`, the service reuses the current credentials. If set to `false`, a new service
ID and API key is generated each time that the secret is read or accessed.

CertificateSecretMetadata.description: Metadata properties that describe a certificate secret.

algorithm.description:
The identifier for the cryptographic algorthim that was used by the issuing certificate authority to
sign the ceritificate.

key_algorithm.description:
The identifier for the cryptographic algorithm that was used to generate the public key that is
associated with the certificate.

common_name.description: The fully qualified domain name or host domain name that is defined for the certificate.

intermediate_included.description: Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated intermediate certificate.

private_key_included.description: Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated private key.

GetConfig.description: Configuration for the specified secret type.

GetConfigElements.description: Properties that describe a list of configurations.

IAMCredentialsSecretEngineRootConfig.description: Configuration for the IAM credentials engine.

api_key.description:
An IBM Cloud API key that has the capability to create and manage service IDs.

The API key must be assigned the Editor platform role on the Access Groups Service and the Operator platform
role on the IAM Identity Service. For more information, see [Configuring the IAM secrets engine](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-iam-credentials#configure-iam-secrets-engine-api).

api_key_hash.description: The hash value of the IBM Cloud API key that is used to create and manage service IDs.

PublicCertSecretEngineRootConfig.description: Configuration for the public certificates engine.

certificate_authorities.description: The certificate authority configurations that are associated with your instance.

dns_providers.description: The DNS provider configurations that are associated with your instance.

ConfigElementDef.description: The configuration to add or update.

config.description: The configuration to define for the specified secret type.

LetsEncryptConfig.description: Properties that describe a Let's Encrypt configuration.

private_key.description: The private key that is associated with your ACME account.

CloudInternetServicesConfig.description: Properties that describe an IBM Cloud Internet Services (CIS) configuration.

cis_crn.description: The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that is associated with the CIS instance.

cis_apikey.description:
An IBM Cloud API key that has the capability to list domains in your CIS instance.

To grant Secrets Manager the ability to view the CIS instance and all of its domains, the
API key must be assigned the Reader service role on Internet Services (`internet-svcs`).

If you need to manage specific domains, you can assign the Manager role. For production
environments, it is recommended that you assign the Reader access role, and then use the
[IAM Policy Management API](https://cloud.ibm.com/apidocs/iam-policy-management#create-policy)
to control specific domains. For more information, see the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-prepare-order-certificates#authorize-specific-domains).

ClassicInfrastructureConfig.description: Properties that describe an IBM Cloud classic infrastructure (SoftLayer) configuration.

classic_infrastructure_username.description: The username that is associated with your classic infrastructure account.

ConfigElementMetadata.description: Properties that describe a configuration element.

SetSecretPolicyRotation.description: The request body for secret-level rotation policies.

SecretPolicyRotation.description: Properties that describe a rotation policy.

type.description: The MIME type that represents the policy. Currently, only the default is supported.

interval.description: Specifies the length of the secret rotation time interval.

unit.description: Specifies the units for the secret rotation time interval.

GetSecretPolicy.description: Properties that describe a rotation policy.

id.description: The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the policy.

crn.description: The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies your cloud resources.

creation_date.description: The date the policy was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.

created_by.description: The unique identifier for the entity that created the policy.

last_update_date.description: Updates when the policy is replaced or modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.

updated_by.description: The unique identifier for the entity that updated the policy.

GetSecretPolicyRotation.description: Properties that describe a rotation policy.

version_id.description: The ID of the secret version.

version_creation_date.description: The date that the version of the secret was created.

version_created_by.description: The unique identifier for the entity that created the secret version.

expiration_date.description:
The date the secret material expires. The date format follows RFC 3339.

You can set an expiration date on supported secret types at their creation. If you create a secret without
specifying an expiration date, the secret does not expire. The `expiration_date` field is supported for the
following secret types:

- `arbitrary`
- `username_password`

certificate_expiration_date.description: The date that the certificate expires. The date format follows RFC 3339.

ttl.description:
The time-to-live (TTL) or lease duration to assign to generated credentials.

For `iam_credentials` secrets, the TTL defines for how long each generated API key remains valid. The value
can be either an integer that specifies the number of seconds, or the string representation of a duration,
such as `120m` or `24h`.

username.description: The username to assign to this secret.

password.description: The password to assign to this secret.

metadata.description: The metadata that describes the resource array.

collection_type.description: The type of resources in the resource array.

collection_total.description: The number of elements in the resource array.

error_message.description: A human-readable message that provides details about the error.

message.description: A human-readable message that provides details about the error.

not_before.description: The date the certificate validity period begins.

not_after.description: The date the certificate validity period ends.

SecretActionBody.description: The properties to update for the secret.

SecretCreateUpdatePolicyBody.description: The policy to create or update.

descriptions:
Creates a secret group that you can use to organize secrets and control who on your team has access to them.

A successful request returns the ID value of the secret group, along with other metadata. To learn more about secret groups, check out the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-secret-groups).
The metadata that describes the resource array.
A collection of resources.
The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret group.

Deletes a secret group by specifying the ID of the secret group.

**Note:** To delete a secret group, it must be empty. If you need to remove a secret group that contains secrets, you must first [delete the secrets](#delete-secret) that are associated with the group.

Creates a secret or imports an existing value that you can use to access or authenticate to a protected resource.

Use this method to either generate or import an existing secret, such as an arbitrary value or a TLS certificate, that you can manage in your Secrets Manager service instance. A successful request stores the secret in your dedicated instance based on the secret type and data that you specify. The response returns the ID value of the secret, along with other metadata.

To learn more about the types of secrets that you can create with Secrets Manager, check out the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-what-is-secret).
The secret type.

The number of secrets to retrieve. By default, list operations return the first 200 items. To retrieve a different set of items, use `limit` with `offset` to page through your available resources.

**Usage:** If you have 20 secrets in your instance, and you want to retrieve only the first 5 secrets, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?limit=5`.

The number of secrets to skip. By specifying `offset`, you retrieve a subset of items that starts with the `offset` value. Use `offset` with `limit` to page through your available resources.

**Usage:** If you have 100 secrets in your instance, and you want to retrieve secrets 26 through 50, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?offset=25&limit=25`.

Filter secrets that contain the specified string. The fields that are searched include: id, name, description, labels, secret_type.

**Usage:** If you want to list only the secrets that contain the string "text", use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?search=text`.

Sort a list of secrets by the specified field.

**Usage:** To sort a list of secrets by their creation date, use
`../secrets/{secret-type}?sort_by=creation_date`.

Filter secrets by groups.

You can apply multiple filters by using a comma-separated list of secret group IDs. If you need to filter secrets that are in the default secret group, use the `default` keyword.

**Usage:** To retrieve a list of secrets that are associated with an existing secret group or the default group, use `../secrets?groups={secret_group_ID},default`.

Retrieves a secret and its details by specifying the ID of the secret.

A successful request returns the secret data that is associated with your secret, along with other metadata. To view only the details of a specified secret without retrieving its value, use the [Get secret metadata](#get-secret-metadata) method.
The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret.
The action to perform on the specified secret.
The properties to update for the secret.

Retrieves a version of a secret by specifying the ID of the version or the alias `previous`.

A successful request returns the secret data that is associated with the specified version of your secret, along with other metadata.
The secret type. Supported options include: imported_cert.

The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret version. You can also use `previous` to retrieve the previous version.

**Note:** To find the version ID of a secret, use the [Get secret metadata](#get-secret-metadata) method and check the response details.

Retrieves the details of a secret by specifying the ID.

A successful request returns only metadata about the secret, such as its name and creation date. To retrieve the value of a secret, use the [Get a secret](#get-secret) or [Get a version of a secret](#get-secret-version) methods.

Updates the metadata of a secret, such as its name or description.

To update the actual contents of a secret, rotate the secret by using the [Invoke an action on a secret](#update-secret) method.

Creates or updates one or more policies, such as an [automatic rotation policy](http://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-rotate-secrets#auto-rotate-secret), for the specified secret.
The type of policy that is associated with the specified secret.

Sets the configuration for the specified secret type.

Use this method to configure the IAM credentials (`iam_credentials`) engine for your service instance. Looking to set up certificate ordering? To configure the public certificates (`public_cert`) engine, use the [Add a configuration](#create_config_element) method.

An IBM Cloud API key that has the capability to create and manage service IDs.

The API key must be assigned the Editor platform role on the Access Groups Service and the Operator platform role on the IAM Identity Service. For more information, see [Configuring the IAM secrets engine](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-iam-credentials#configure-iam-secrets-engine-api).

Adds a configuration element to the specified secret type.

Use this method to define the configurations that are required to enable the  public certificates (`public_cert`) engine. You can add up to 10 certificate authority and DNS provider configurations for your instance.
The configuration element to define or manage.
The human-readable name to assign to your configuration.
The type of configuration. Value options differ depending on the `config_element` property that you want to define.
The configuration to define for the specified secret type.
The name of your configuration.
The createSecretGroup options.
The type of resources in the resource array.
The number of elements in the resource array.
Properties that describe a secret group.

A human-readable name to assign to your secret group.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a name for your secret group.

An extended description of your secret group.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a description for your secret group.
The date the secret group was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.
Updates when the metadata of the secret group is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The MIME type that represents the secret group.
The getSecretGroup options.
The updateSecretGroupMetadata options.
Metadata properties to update for a secret group.
The deleteSecretGroup options.
The createSecret options.

A human-readable alias to assign to your secret.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as an alias for your secret.

An extended description of your secret.

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a description for your secret.

The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the secret group to assign to this secret.

If you omit this parameter, your secret is assigned to the `default` secret group.

Labels that you can use to filter for secrets in your instance.

Up to 30 labels can be created. Labels can be between 2-30 characters, including spaces. Special characters not permitted include the angled bracket, comma, colon, ampersand, and vertical pipe character (|).

To protect your privacy, do not use personal data, such as your name or location, as a label for your secret.
The secret state based on NIST SP 800-57. States are integers and correspond to the Pre-activation = 0, Active = 1,  Suspended = 2, Deactivated = 3, and Destroyed = 5 values.
A text representation of the secret state.
The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies your Secrets Manager resource.
The date the secret was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The unique identifier for the entity that created the secret.
Updates when the actual secret is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The number of versions that are associated with a secret.
An array that contains metadata for each secret version. For more information on the metadata properties, see [Get secret version metadata](#get-secret-version-metadata).

The date the secret material expires. The date format follows RFC 3339.

You can set an expiration date on supported secret types at their creation. If you create a secret without specifying an expiration date, the secret does not expire. The `expiration_date` field is supported for the following secret types:

- `arbitrary`
- `username_password`.
The new secret data to assign to the secret.
The username to assign to this secret.
The password to assign to this secret.

The date that the secret is scheduled for automatic rotation.

The service automatically creates a new version of the secret on its next rotation date. This field exists only for secrets that can be auto-rotated and have an existing rotation policy.

The time-to-live (TTL) or lease duration to assign to generated credentials.

For `iam_credentials` secrets, the TTL defines for how long each generated API key remains valid. The value can be either an integer that specifies the number of seconds, or the string representation of a duration, such as `120m` or `24h`.

The access groups that define the capabilities of the service ID and API key that are generated for an
`iam_credentials` secret.

**Tip:** To find the ID of an access group, go to **Manage > Access (IAM) > Access groups** in the IBM Cloud console. Select the access group to inspect, and click **Details** to view its ID.

The API key that is generated for this secret.

After the secret reaches the end of its lease (see the `ttl` field), the API key is deleted automatically. If you want to continue to use the same API key for future read operations, see the `reuse_api_key` field.
The service ID under which the API key (see the `api_key` field) is created. This service ID is added to the access groups that you assign for this secret.

Set to `true` to reuse the service ID and API key for this secret.

Use this field to control whether to use the same service ID and API key for future read operations on this secret. If set to `true`, the service reuses the current credentials. If set to `false`, a new service ID and API key is generated each time that the secret is read or accessed.
The contents of your certificate. The data must be formatted on a single line with embedded newline characters.
The private key to associate with the certificate. The data must be formatted on a single line with embedded newline characters.
The intermediate certificate to associate with the root certificate. The data must be formatted on a single line with embedded newline characters.
The unique serial number that was assigned to the certificate by the issuing certificate authority.
The identifier for the cryptographic algorthim that was used by the issuing certificate authority to sign the ceritificate.
The identifier for the cryptographic algorithm that was used to generate the public key that is associated with the certificate.
The distinguished name that identifies the entity that signed and issued the certificate.
The fully qualified domain name or host domain name that is defined for the certificate.
Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated intermediate certificate.
Indicates whether the certificate was imported with an associated private key.
The alternative names that are defined for the certificate.

Determines whether your issued certificate is bundled with intermediate certificates.

Set to `false` for the certificate file to contain only the issued certificate.

The name of the certificate authority configuration.

To view a list of your configured authorities, use the [List configurations API](#get-secret-config-element).

The name of the DNS provider configuration.

To view a list of your configured authorities, use the [List configurations API](#get-secret-config-element).
Issuance information that is associated with your certificate.
The date the certificate validity period begins.
The date the certificate validity period ends.

Determines whether Secrets Manager rotates your certificate automatically.

If set to `true`, the service reorders your certificate 31 days before it expires. To access the previous  version of the certifcate, you can use the [Get a version of a secret](#get-secret-version) method.

Determines whether Secrets Manager rotates the private key for your certificate automatically.

If set to `true`, the service generates and stores a new private key for your rotated certificate.
The date the certificate was ordered. The date format follows RFC 3339.

An code that identifies an issuance error.

This field, along with `error_message`, is returned when Secrets Manager successfully processes your request, but a certificate is unable to be issued by the certificate authority.
A human-readable message that provides details about the issuance error.
Indicates whether the issued certificate is bundled with intermediate certificates.
Indicates whether the issued certificate is configured with an automatic rotation policy.
The name that was assigned to the certificate authority configuration.
The name that was assigned to the DNS provider configuration.
Properties that describe a secret.
The date that the certificate expires. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The identifier for the cryptographic algorthim to be used by the issuing certificate authority to sign the ceritificate.
The identifier for the cryptographic algorithm to be used to generate the public key that is associated with the certificate.
The fully qualified domain name or host domain name for the certificate.
The listSecrets options.
Properties that describe a list of secrets.
The listAllSecrets options.
The getSecret options.
The updateSecret options.
The new secret data to assign to an `arbitrary` secret.
Determine whether keys should be rotated.
The new password to assign to a `username_password` secret.
The new data to associate with the certificate.
The new private key to associate with the certificate.
The new intermediate certificate to associate with the certificate.
The service ID that you want to delete. It is deleted together with its API key.
The request body of a `rotate` action.
The request body of a rotate certificate action.
Delete the credentials that are associated with an `iam_credentials` secret.
The deleteSecret options.
The getSecretVersion options.
Properties that describe the version of a secret.
The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies the secret.
The ID of the secret version.
The date that the version of the secret was created.
The unique identifier for the entity that created the secret version.
The contents of the certificate.
The private key that is associated with the certificate.
The intermediate certificate that is associated with the certificate.
The getSecretVersionMetadata options.
Indicates whether the version of the secret was created by automatic rotation.
Properties that describe a secret version.
The getSecretMetadata options.
The metadata of a secret.
The unique ID of the secret.
The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies the resource.
Updates when any part of the secret metadata is modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The number of versions the secret has.

For `iam_credentials` secrets, this field controls whether to use the same service ID and API key for future read operations on this secret. If set to `true`, the service reuses the current credentials. If set to `false`, a new service ID and API key is generated each time that the secret is read or accessed.
Metadata properties that describe an arbitrary secret.
Metadata properties that describe a username_password secret.
Metadata properties that describe a iam_credentials secret.
Metadata properties that describe a certificate secret.
Metadata properties that describe a public certificate secret.
Indicates whether the certificate was ordered with an associated intermediate certificate.
Indicates whether the certificate was ordered with an associated private key.
The updateSecretMetadata options.
The putPolicy options.
Properties that describe a rotation policy.
The MIME type that represents the policy. Currently, only the default is supported.
Specifies the length of the secret rotation time interval.
Specifies the units for the secret rotation time interval.
The secret rotation time interval.
The `public_cert` secret rotation policy.
The v4 UUID that uniquely identifies the policy.
The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that uniquely identifies your cloud resources.
The date the policy was created. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The unique identifier for the entity that created the policy.
Updates when the policy is replaced or modified. The date format follows RFC 3339.
The unique identifier for the entity that updated the policy.
The getPolicy options.
The putConfig options.

Configuration for the specified secret type.
The certificate authority configurations that are associated with your instance.
The DNS provider configurations that are associated with your instance.
The hash value of the IBM Cloud API key that is used to create and manage service IDs.
Properties that describe a configuration element.
Configuration for the public certificates engine.
Configuration for the IAM credentials engine.
The createConfigElement options.
The private key that is associated with your ACME account.
The Cloud Resource Name (CRN) that is associated with the CIS instance.

An IBM Cloud API key that has the capability to list domains in your CIS instance.

To grant Secrets Manager the ability to view the CIS instance and all of its domains, the API key must be assigned the Reader service role on Internet Services (`internet-svcs`).

If you need to manage specific domains, you can assign the Manager role. For production environments, it is recommended that you assign the Reader access role, and then use the
[IAM Policy Management API](https://cloud.ibm.com/apidocs/iam-policy-management#create-policy) to control specific domains. For more information, see the [docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/secrets-manager?topic=secrets-manager-prepare-order-certificates#authorize-specific-domains).
The username that is associated with your classic infrastructure account.
Your classic infrastructure API key.
Properties that describe a Let's Encrypt configuration.
Properties that describe an IBM Cloud Internet Services (CIS) configuration.
Properties that describe an IBM Cloud classic infrastructure (SoftLayer) configuration.
Properties that describe a configuration.
The configuration to add or update.

DNS providers configuration.
